questions.text: Fig. 1.1 shows a tube full of mercury placed upside down in a dish of mercury. Initially a small piece of glass closes the open end of the tube. The piece of glass is removed and the level of mercury in the inverted tube falls, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

parts.text: Explain why the level of mercury in the tube falls.
parts.answer: pressure due to mercury (in tube) is greater than pressure due to atmosphere (+ small height of mercury) && (resultant) force downwards and mercury flows out of tube

parts.text: State what is found at point X in Fig. 1.2.
parts.answer: vacuum or nothing or mercury vapour

parts.text: Describe how the tube of mercury in Fig. 1.2 is used to determine a value for the atmospheric pressure in pascals (Pa). You may draw on Fig. 1.2 if you wish. [cite: 17, 18]
parts.answer: height of mercury column mentioned && height of mercury column above level in dish measured && candidate suggests use of p= h ρ g and h in metres (m)

questions.text: A small coin of mass m is initially at rest. It is dropped from a height h above ground level. The coin has a speed v as it hits the ground. The gravitational field strength g is equal to 10 N/kg.

parts.text:
State an expression for:
• the gravitational potential energy of the coin at a height h above ground level
• the kinetic energy of the coin when travelling at a speed v.
parts.answer: mgh and 1/2mv^2

parts.text: The coin is dropped from the top of a building of height 380 m. Determine the speed of the coin as it hits the ground. You may ignore air resistance.
parts.answer: 1/2mv^2 =mgh or v^2 = 2gh or v^2 = 2 x 10 x 380 or v^2 = 7600 && ( ) v = sqrt(2gh) or sqrt(2 x 10 x 380) && 87 m / s

parts.text: When air resistance is negligible, a heavier coin hits the ground at the same speed as a lighter coin when they are both dropped from the same height. Explain why.
parts.answer: both the g.p.e. and the k.e. are proportional to mass or mass cancels out in the equation or they accelerate at the same rate / g

parts.text: When air resistance acts, coins of different masses do not hit the ground at the same speed when they are dropped from the same height. Explain why.
parts.answer: air resistance (force) is a smaller proportion of weight (for heavier coin) && acceleration of heavier coin greater / less affected by air resistance

questions.text: A saucepan of water is placed on an electric hotplate and the water is brought to the boil. As the water boils, it changes from a liquid into a gas.

parts.text: Describe, in terms of the molecules, three ways in which a gas differs from a liquid.
parts.answer: any three from: molecules / they are further apart && forces between molecules / them smaller && molecules / they move in straight lines (between collisions) && potential energy of molecules / them greater && gas molecules move freely/randomly but liquid molecules slide over each other

parts.text: In order to keep the liquid boiling, it is necessary to keep the hotplate switched on. Explain why energy must be supplied in order to turn a liquid at its boiling point into a gas.
parts.answer: (molecules separated against) intermolecular forces / bonds && work is done as molecules separate or bonds broken or latent heat supplied

questions.text: Fig. 4.1 represents the electromagnetic spectrum. The shaded region in the middle is the visible light spectrum.

parts.text: State the name of the component labelled: A, B, C. [cite: 33]
parts.answer: (A:) ultraviolet (radiation) && (B:) infra-red (radiation) && (C:) microwaves && all three correct

parts.text: State the name of the component of the electromagnetic spectrum that has: the greatest frequency, the smallest wavelength. [cite: 33]
parts.answer: gamma-rays and gamma-rays

parts.text: Explain how X-rays are used to produce an image of a broken bone in a patient's leg. [cite: 34]
parts.answer: X-rays pass through flesh and not (to the same extent) through bone && X-rays detected photographically or (digital) detector behind bone && no / less exposure / detection reveals bone or exposure / detection reveals break

questions.text: An electronic balance is calibrated to display the weight of an object that is placed on its top plate. Fig. 5.1 shows the balance with an empty measuring cylinder on the top plate. The gravitational field strength g is equal to 10 N/kg.

parts.text: Using Fig. 5.2, determine the density of the oil. [cite: 40]
parts.answer: two pairs of results from the line and separated by > 50 cm^3 && or (ρ) = m / V use of results to obtain gradient or any mass / corresponding volume && W = mg or (ρ =) gradient / g or 0.00881 (N / cm^3) < ρ < 0.00895 (N / cm^3) && 0.000881 kg / cm^3 < ρ < 0.000895 kg / cm^3 or 0.881 g / cm^3 < ρ < 0.895 g / cm^3

questions.text: A 60 W filament lamp is powered by the 240 V mains electricity supply. The lamp is switched on.

parts.text: Calculate the current in the lamp. [cite: 44]
Calculate the resistance of the lamp. [cite: 46]
The lamp is now unplugged from the mains supply and connected in series with two 1.5 V cells. Fig. 6.1 is the circuit diagram. State the reading on the voltmeter. [cite: 48, 49]
State and explain how the resistance of the lamp now differs from the value calculated in (a)(ii). [cite: 50]
parts.answer: resistance is smaller && (filament at a) lower temperature

parts.text: When a filament lamp blows, it very often does so immediately after being switched on. Suggest why this is the case. [cite: 51, 52]
parts.answer: current surge (due to lower resistance when cold)

questions.text: Table 7.1 shows the composition of four neutral atoms and one atom that has been ionised. These five particles are labelled P, Q, R, S and T. The charge on an electron is -1.6 x 10^-19 C.

parts.text: State which of P, Q, R, S and T is the ionised atom. [cite: 56]
parts.answer: (atomic particle) Q

parts.text: State the size and the sign of the charge on the ionised atom. [cite: 57]
State which pair from P, Q, R, S and T are isotopes of the same element. [cite: 58]
parts.answer: (atomic particle) Q and (atomic particle) S

parts.text: One of the atoms is a radioactive isotope that decays to produce one of the other atoms. Deduce which atom decays in this way. [cite: 59, 60]
parts.answer: (atomic particle) R

parts.text: Deduce which atom is the product of this decay.
parts.answer: (atomic particle) S

parts.text: Deduce which type of radioactive decay occurs.
parts.answer: beta-(particle) emission

parts.text: The half-life for this radioactive decay is 33 years. A radioactive sample contains a large number of the atoms that decay in this way. Determine the fraction of this number of atoms that will decay in 99 years. [cite: 61, 62, 63]
parts.answer: 99 / 33 or 3 half-lives && 1 / 2^3 or 1 / 8 (remain) && 7 / 8

parts.text: A small electric component in a circuit needs to be protected from a strong, external magnetic field. Describe how this is done and state any material used. [cite: 66, 67]
parts.answer: surround the component with a box or use of iron mentioned && surround the component with (a box of) iron

parts.text: Electromagnets have many domestic and industrial applications. In the space, draw a diagram of a simple electromagnet. [cite: 67, 68]
parts.answer: solenoid and d.c. power supply and switch && core && iron core

parts.text: State and describe in detail one use of an electromagnet.
parts.answer: named or described use && what happens when electromagnet is switched on && current causes magnetisation or description of what happens when electromagnet is switched off

parts.text: Fig. 8.2 shows a solenoid connected to a sensitive ammeter. Explain what is observed on the ammeter when a student:
inserts an N-pole of a bar magnet slowly into the right-hand end of the solenoid.
parts.answer: ammeters deflects / shows a reading && magnetic field lines cut by solenoid or changing magnetic field in coil && e.m.f. / voltage induced

parts.text: holds the bar magnet stationary in the solenoid.
parts.answer: no deflection and no (magnetic) field lines cut or constant field

parts.text: withdraws the N-pole of the magnet quickly from the right-hand end of the solenoid.
parts.answer: larg(er) deflection && opposite deflection && field lines cut in opposite sense or opposite change in (magnetic) field or field lines cut faster

questions.text: Fig. 9.1 shows the structure of a water cooler that is used to supply cold water to the workers in a hot office.

parts.text: The reservoir of water in the plastic container is at room temperature. It does not mix with the cold water in the tank below. Explain why. [cite: 75, 76]
parts.answer: it is less dense (than the cooler water) && it floats on the cooler water / cooler water cannot move up / cooler water remains on the bottom

parts.text: When the tap is opened, water at room temperature from the reservoir flows down into the tank. Cold water from the tank flows through the plastic pipe and out of the tap. Cold liquid from the refrigeration unit is pumped through the copper pipe and thermal energy passes through the copper to this liquid. Suggest why this pipe is made from copper. [cite: 77, 78, 79, 80]
parts.answer: copper / metal is a good (thermal) conductor

parts.text: Explain, in terms of free electrons, how thermal energy is transferred through the copper.
parts.answer: vibrating atoms / ions / particles / molecules or electrons gain energy && atoms / ions / particles / molecules hit the electrons or electrons travel (a long distance through the copper) && electrons hit / transfer energy to (distant) atoms / ions / particles / molecules

parts.text: As the water near the copper pipe cools, it begins to mix with the rest of the water in the tank. Explain how this happens. [cite: 82, 83]
parts.answer: it contracts or its density increases && it sinks && less dense / warmer water rises or sets up a convection current

parts.text: The tap is opened and water at 21°C flows from the reservoir into the tank. The specific heat capacity of water is 4200J /(kg°C). Calculate the thermal energy that is removed from 250g of this water to reduce its temperature to 7°C. [cite: 83, 84]
Describe the motion of the molecules in a liquid which is at a uniform temperature throughout.
parts.answer: any two from: molecules / they move in clusters && slide over each other && molecules / they move throughout the liquid

parts.text: State what happens to the motion of the molecules in a liquid as the temperature of the liquid decreases.
parts.answer: average speed / kinetic energy decreases

questions.text: Visible light is one component of the electromagnetic spectrum.

parts.text: State the speed of light in a vacuum.
State the colours of the visible spectrum.
parts.answer: red orange yellow green blue indigo violet (any order)

parts.text: An object O of height 3.0cm is placed 4.0cm from the centre of a diverging lens. Fig. 10.1 shows the object O, the diverging lens and the two focal points (principal focuses), F1 and F2, of the lens. Determine the focal length of this lens. [cite: 90, 91, 92]
The diverging lens produces an image of object O. On Fig. 10.1, by drawing rays from the tip of O, locate this image and label it I.
parts.answer: any two rays drawn from: paraxial ray that refracts and seems to come from F1 && ray through the optical centre of lens && ray that aims for F2 but refracts and emerges paraxially && rays traced back to point && (point) labelled I and rest of image drawn down to the principal axis

parts.text: Determine the height of the image.
Determine the magnification of the image.
parts.answer: candidate's 10(c)(iii) / 3.0 evaluated

parts.text: State two ways in which a virtual image differs from a real image. [cite: 96]
parts.answer: any two from: a real image can be projected on to a screen && light actually passes through a real image && on same side (of lens) as object or on opposite side of mirror to object

parts.text: State one use for a diverging lens. [cite: 97]
parts.answer: correction of short-sight / myopia

parts.text: Light passing from air into glass refracts in a similar way to a water wave passing from deep water into shallow water. Fig. 10.2 represents light passing from air into glass at an angle to the surface. One side of a wavefront strikes the glass before the other side. Explain why the wavefronts change direction as the light enters the glass. [cite: 98, 99, 100, 101]
parts.answer: light travels more slowly in glass or light changes speed && one side / left-hand side of wavefront slows down first && wavelength decreases or wavefront travels a shorter distance in the same time
